protocols.name: Florence
protocols.headline: Depth-first execution, streamlined governance
protocols.debate: Baking Accounts removed due to undocumented breaking changes

protocols.name: Granada
protocols.headline: 30-second blocks, liquidity baking
protocols.debate: Liquidity Baking controversial: protocol-level DeFi subsidy debate began

history.title: The Liquidity Baking Wars Begin
history.subtitle: The controversial subsidy that changed Tezos governance forever

sections.heading: The Original Sin
sections.content:
Granada introduced Liquidity Baking — a forced protocol-level subsidy of 2.5 tez per block to the tzBTC/XTZ liquidity pool. Every single block, the protocol would mint new tez and inject them into a specific DeFi pool.

This was unprecedented. No other blockchain had ever used protocol-level inflation to subsidize a specific trading pair. Critics called it "protocol-level market manipulation." Supporters argued it was essential for creating deep, decentralized liquidity for tez.

left.name: Pro-LB
left.position: Deep liquidity is essential for network health. Protocol-level subsidies create reliable, censorship-resistant liquidity that can't be withdrawn on a whim.
left.quote: Liquidity Baking provides something no centralized exchange can — permanent, permissionless liquidity.

right.name: Anti-LB
right.position: Forcing inflation to subsidize one specific pool is market manipulation. The protocol shouldn't pick DeFi winners.
right.quote: This is the protocol choosing to inflate the currency to subsidize a specific trading pair. That's not neutral monetary policy.

sections.heading: The Escape Hatch
sections.content:
Granada included a safety valve: bakers could vote to turn off Liquidity Baking via an "escape hatch" mechanism. If more than 50% of bakers voted to escape, LB would be deactivated after a sunset period.

This escape hatch would become the central battleground of Tezos governance for the next three upgrades.

sections.heading: Why It Matters
sections.content:
Granada set the precedent that Tezos could make economic policy at the protocol level — not just technical upgrades. Once that box was opened, every subsequent upgrade became a debate about economic philosophy.

The Liquidity Baking Trilogy (Granada → Ithaca → Jakarta) consumed three consecutive protocol cycles with governance warfare over a single feature. Granada was where it all began.

protocols.name: Ithaca
protocols.headline: Tenderbake: deterministic finality
protocols.debate: Extended Liquidity Baking sunset by ~10 months

history.title: The LB Extension Wars
history.subtitle: Tenderbake consensus arrived, but Liquidity Baking stole the show

sections.heading: Why Deterministic Finality Matters
sections.content:
Before Ithaca, Tezos used Emmy* — a Nakamoto-style consensus with probabilistic finality. Tenderbake replaced it with a BFT algorithm where blocks are mathematically final after 2 confirmations.

The advantage isn't just speed. Deterministic finality means simpler implementations, clearer specifications, and more tractable mathematical proofs. Every PBFT-family algorithm is conceptually easier to reason about than probabilistic alternatives.

Ethereum still uses probabilistic finality — technically, transactions can reorg. Solana uses a probabilistic approach too. Tezos blocks are mathematically final. Period.

sections.heading: Tenderbake vs LB Drama
sections.content:
Ithaca's headline feature was Tenderbake — a major consensus upgrade bringing deterministic finality to Tezos. It was a genuinely significant technical achievement.

But the governance conversation was dominated by Liquidity Baking. Ithaca extended the LB sunset by approximately 10 months (~20 voting periods), keeping the controversial subsidy alive.

sections.heading: The Threshold Battle
sections.content:
The key compromise: Ithaca lowered the escape hatch threshold from 50% to 33%. This meant it would be easier for the community to turn off LB if sentiment shifted.

The community was genuinely split:

• "Valuable liquidity" camp: LB provides essential infrastructure, removing it would damage the ecosystem
• "Inappropriate subsidy" camp: Protocol shouldn't force inflation for one specific pool, especially when XTZ/BTC was trending down

sections.heading: Why It Matters
sections.content:
Ithaca showed that once economic policy enters protocol governance, it's nearly impossible to remove. The LB debate consumed oxygen that could have celebrated Tenderbake — one of the most important technical upgrades in Tezos history.

The lowered threshold was a compromise, but it satisfied nobody fully. The anti-LB faction wanted it gone; the pro-LB faction worried about its survival.

history.title: The Toggle Vote: LB Gets Permanent
history.subtitle: Liquidity Baking's escape hatch became a permanent governance feature

sections.heading: From Escape to Toggle
sections.content:
Jakarta transformed the LB "Escape Hatch" into a more sophisticated "Toggle Vote" system. Instead of a binary escape mechanism, bakers now had three options: On, Off, or Pass.

This made deactivation reversible — LB could be turned off and then turned back on through ongoing democratic votes. Technically elegant, but it effectively enshrined LB as a permanent governance debate.

sections.heading: The Entrenchment Concern
sections.content:
Critics saw the Toggle Vote as further entrenching a controversial mechanism into the protocol. Rather than resolving the LB debate, Jakarta made it a permanent fixture of Tezos governance.

The entities benefiting from LB — farmers extracting yield from the subsidy — were unlikely to vote to turn it off. The toggle vote structure arguably favored continuation over removal.

sections.heading: Why It Matters
sections.content:
Jakarta completed the Liquidity Baking Trilogy. Three consecutive protocol upgrades had their governance conversations dominated by a single controversial feature.

The Toggle Vote became the template for ongoing economic policy debates in Tezos — a permanent democratic mechanism for managing protocol-level economic interventions.

protocols.name: Lima
protocols.headline: Consensus keys separate baking from funds
protocols.debate: Timelocks disabled due to security vulnerability

protocols.name: Oxford
protocols.headline: Adaptive Issuance foundations (disabled)
protocols.debate: MAJOR: First Oxford REJECTED at Promotion. AI/Staking too complex, bugs found. Oxford 2 passed with AI disabled.

history.title: The First Rejection: Oxford vs Oslo
history.subtitle: The community proved it could say no — and nearly broke in the process

sections.heading: A Historic First
sections.content:
Oxford became the first protocol proposal ever rejected in Tezos history. After years of upgrades passing through governance smoothly, the community drew a line.

The rejection happened at the Promotion stage — Oxford had already passed Exploration and Cooldown, but when it came time for final adoption, bakers said no.

left.name: Team Oxford
left.position: Adaptive Issuance with conservative parameters: 5% maximum issuance, 1.5% initial rate. Cautious approach to new economic mechanism.
left.quote: Oxford represents a careful, well-tested approach to Adaptive Issuance that minimizes risk.

right.name: Team Oslo
right.position: Higher initial rates (3% vs 1.5%) and higher maximum (7.5% vs 5%). More generous to stakers, faster path to target ratio.
right.quote: Oslo's parameters better incentivize the transition to staking and avoid punishing early adopters.

sections.heading: The Aftermath
sections.content:
After rejection, Oxford was resubmitted as "Oxford 2" with Adaptive Issuance disabled — the economic features stripped out pending more community discussion. The technical upgrades passed; the economic policy was shelved.

This set the stage for Paris (which finally activated Adaptive Issuance) and ultimately Quebec (where the economic warfare reached its peak).

sections.heading: Why It Matters
sections.content:
Oxford proved that Tezos governance wasn't rubber-stamping. The community could and would reject core developer proposals when they disagreed with the economic direction.

This was the moment bakers realized their votes actually mattered for economic policy — and it emboldened the community challenges that would define Quebec.

protocols.name: Paris
protocols.headline: 10-second blocks, DAL launches
protocols.debate: Reintroduced AI with major revisions after Oxford rejection feedback

protocols.name: Quebec
protocols.headline: 8-second blocks, Adaptive Maximum — the most contested upgrade in Tezos history
protocols.debate: Quebec vs Qena: 6-month economic governance battle. Qena42 won the Proposal vote (59.9%) but was killed in Exploration after a core developer bug advisory caused no quorum. Qena variants consistently won majority support but couldn't clear the 80% supermajority or maintain quorum. First time community seriously challenged core developer economic proposals.

history.title: The Quebec/Qena Wars: A Battle for Tezos' Economic Soul
history.subtitle: The most contested upgrade in Tezos history — a 6-month governance crisis

sections.heading: The Spark
sections.content: When Paris activated in June 2024, it introduced Adaptive Issuance — Tezos' automatic inflation adjustment targeting 50% staked. But by September, Nomadic Labs proposed Quebec A and B with an "adaptive maximum" curve that would cap issuance as staking approached the target. The community response was immediate and fierce.

events.text: Paris activates with Adaptive Issuance. Target: 50% staked.
Nomadic Labs announces Quebec A/B with adaptive maximum curve. Quebec B also reduces delegation weight from 1/2 to 1/3.
Tez Capital fires back with Qena — all technical upgrades, no economic changes. "Adaptive issuance hasn't matured yet."
Period 131: Qena wins Proposal vote but gets only 77% in Exploration — fails the 80% supermajority by 3%.
Tez Capital publishes economic analysis, launches Qena42 — moves target to 42%, cuts delegation weight to 1/3.
Period 133: Qena42 wins Proposal vote with 59.9% of upvotes (141.55M vs Quebec's 94.56M). Advances to Exploration.
Period 134: Core developers publish bug advisory for Qena42. Many bakers abstain — Exploration fails with no quorum.
Tez Capital launches Q3NA — accepts 50% target and adaptive maximum, but turns off Liquidity Baking to cut issuance by 0.5%/year.
Quebec (B variant) ultimately activates with 8-second blocks and adaptive maximum.

sections.heading: The Core Dispute
sections.content:
At its heart, this was a philosophical battle. Quebec proposed an algorithmic curve to automatically reduce maximum issuance as staking approached 50%. At that point, issuance would be capped at just 1% annually.

Tez Capital argued this was premature — Adaptive Issuance had only been live for 4 months. They warned that Quebec would cause rewards to "drop by as much as one-third" and that people were being attracted to stake with high APY promises without being told about the upcoming cuts.

left.name: Team Quebec
left.position: Controlled descent via adaptive maximum curve. Prevent excessive inflation. Long-term sustainability through automatic adjustment.
left.quote: Adaptive Maximum makes the Tezos protocol able to better adapt staking rewards to changing network conditions without governance intervention.

right.name: Team Qena
right.position: Let natural market forces work. Adaptive Issuance needs time to mature. Simpler approaches like adjusting the staking target or removing Liquidity Baking.
right.quote: If my bank were to change interest rates without informing me, I would immediately move my funds elsewhere and never return.

sections.heading: The Trust Crisis
sections.content:
The most emotionally charged moment came when Tez Capital accused the ecosystem of "misleading stakers" — encouraging people to stake with promises of high APYs while quietly planning to slash those rewards via Quebec.

"Right now, there's a heavy push to attract stakers with promises of high APYs, but there has been little communication in the context of what comes next... APYs could drop to half, a third, or even a quarter of what they are now."

This struck at fundamental questions of community trust and baker responsibility.

sections.heading: The Compromise Attempts
sections.content:
Tez Capital evolved through three proposals, each incorporating lessons:

• Qena: No economic changes — just technical progress. Won Proposal vote, got 77% in Exploration but failed the 80% supermajority by 3%.
• Qena42: Moved staking target to 42%, cut delegation weight to 1/3. Won the next Proposal vote with 59.9% of upvotes — but died from no quorum in Exploration after a core developer bug advisory caused mass abstention.
• Q3NA: Accept the 50% target and adaptive maximum, but turn off Liquidity Baking to cut issuance by 0.5%/year — a genuine compromise attempt.

sections.heading: Why It Matters
sections.content:
The Quebec/Qena wars established that economic protocol changes require higher scrutiny than technical ones. The community demonstrated it could produce viable alternative implementations, engage in sophisticated economic debates, and force genuine compromise through sustained democratic pressure.

This was the moment Tezos governance grew up — the first time bakers seriously challenged core developer economic proposals instead of rubber-stamping them.
